We Need a Solution. Period.

25/10/2019

Abi Pyne discusses the York based organisation fighting period poverty both at home and abroad, and the small things we can all do to make a difference

Image by Free the Flow

By Jenna Luxon

Yorkâ€™s very own â€˜Free the Flowâ€™ is a group at the forefront of tackling period poverty. Their mission; to ensure the free and equal provision of sanitary products for all of us who menstruate, both here on the uni campus and internationally. This small yet mighty organisation has recently partnered with Project Gambia, establishing the â€˜For Now and For Lifeâ€™ movement, aiming to provide long-lasting menstrual aid for communities abroad.

Period poverty is a universal issue that affects us all, whether you menstruate or not. According to the Water Supply & Sanitation Collaborative Council (WSSCC) over 1.2 billion people have limited or no access to sanitary products across the globe. And itâ€™s not just those living in impoverished countries that are included in this statistic. At Free the Flowâ€™s aptly named Menstruation Conversations talk last Saturday, statistics from Plan International UK were quoted revealing that 15% of menstruators in the UK have struggled to afford sanitary products on a monthly basis with 10% being completely unable to afford them.

Horribly, an estimated 137,700 of menstruators in the UK will miss days of school/university as a result of period poverty each year. Meaning it is highly likely that people in your peer group, individuals you see around campus and in lectures, are experiencing some form of period poverty.

Internationally, the crisis is still ever present. Speakers at the event told of their experiences of communities in countries like Bangladesh, Sir Lanka and Nepal, being unable to access sanitary aid due to a whole host of factors. For those individuals in more rural and conservative communities, it is common for the most advanced form of sanitary protection available to be a cloth rag, folded three times over to increase absorption. These make-shift pads are commonly worn for whole days at time, not being changed due to a lack of adequate sanitary waste disposal. This includes a lack of waste disposal in school toilets, meaning children often go whole school days, sat in class in their own menstrual blood, afraid of leakages that might stain their uniform and embarrass them.

In the evening, the rags are washed â€“ soap is only used if the family has access to it putting menstruators at risk of infection and allowing for the easy spread of diseases. If the community water supply is in a public space, make-shift pads have to be washed under the cover of darkness to ensure not being seen. The pads are then hidden and left to dry to be used again the next morning. Concerningly, it isnâ€™t uncommon for the same rag to be used repeatedly for up to three cycles proving extremely unhygienic.

Iâ€™m sure anyone who has ever experienced having a period will agree with me when I state that I canâ€™t imagine anything more uncomfortable and less dignified, especially if I was attending class or a job. Heartbreakingly, it is then unsurprising that UNESCO estimates that school children facing such extreme levels of period poverty in Sub-Saharan Africa miss up too 20% of the school year because of their period, with many dropping out of education all together, putting them at risk of being forced into child marriages.

Even when sanitary items are available and can be afforded there are negative consequences, especially for those in more disadvantaged positions. Many sanitary products on the market globally are non-reusable and non-recyclable. On average, menstruators living in the western-world use up to 22 sanitary products per month, 264 items a year and 11,000 pads or tampons in a lifetime. With roughly half the worldâ€™s population having periods each month, thatâ€™s a staggering amount of waste to deal with. In fact, it is tampons and pads that are amongst the top items found in beach-clean ups here in the UK. This throw-away period culture is unfortunately having a dire impact on our environment, the production and destruction of used sanitary products a huge contributor to the climate-crisis.

And itâ€™s not us here in the UK that are currently reaping the consequences of climate-change. Some communities in Bangladesh are already being heavily affected by flooding as a result of global-warming. Menstruators are forced to wash their sanitary â€˜padsâ€™ in stagnant water, putting both themselves and the wider community at the risk of disease should this sanitary waste contaminate drinking water. Rising water also means a decrease in income as farm land is flooded, meaning less and less disposable income is available for buying sanitary products. In these circumstances, sanitary protection is considered a luxury and not a necessity.

This is why Free the Flowâ€™s â€˜For Now and for Lifeâ€™ movement is so important. To provide communities with one-time-use period products is of course crucial in a crisis but when this aid is no longer available it is highly likely that menstruators will have to revert to ineffective sanitary protection. Free the Flow wants to establish the usage of re-usable products for communities facing period poverty to insure they are not reliant on buying new products for each cycle. To adapt the common phrase, â€˜give someone a fish, theyâ€™ll eat for a day - teach that someone to fish and theyâ€™ll eat for lifeâ€™, if we are able to provide menstruators with long-term, sustainable sanitary products we can ensure safe and effective period protection for individuals potentially for life.

And we can help! By changing our period-habits each month, we can make a difference for those suffering from period poverty. Free the Flow is encouraging menstruators to invest in more sustainable period products for themselves to reduce sanitary waste; menstrual-cups, fabric sanitary pads, reusable underwear and even sea-sponges (which are apparently highly absorbent) are all reusable and long-lasting. While I myself have never used a sea-sponge (although I am curious), I can vouch for the menstrual-cup. Iâ€™m not exaggerating when I say my moon-cup is the best thing Iâ€™ve ever brought. Retailing at between Â£15 to Â£20, these tiny miracles donâ€™t have to be changed for up to 12 hours and have a life time of 10 years!

And you donâ€™t need to search far and wide to find them â€“ York Universityâ€™s own sustainable pop-up store, Scoop sells all sorts of re-usable menstrual products.  By investing in re-usable sanitary items, not only will you save some pennies in the long run, but you also avoid contributing to a climate-crisis which effects those less fortunate communities of menstruators so detrimentally.

It is more pressing now than ever before to stand-behind groups like Free the Flow in order to free menstruators from the clutches of period-poverty. As the climate-crisis grows, it will be menstruators in poorer communities that are the most likely to suffer. Thereâ€™s still time for us to make a change. You can support the â€˜For Now and For Lifeâ€™ movement by donating spare sanitary items, ether by contacting Free the Flow or bringing donations along to their next meeting. If you can, considering investing in sustainable sanitary items to reduce your environmental impact each month. If neither are suitable options, your presence at Free the Flows events is just as valuable as any donation. Help them fight period poverty worldwide by spreading awareness â€“ help them bring period poverty to its knees.

Free the Flow are on contactable on Facebook via @freetheflowyork
To find out more about Project Gambia, search https://www.projectgambia.org.uk/
To find out Scoopâ€™s opening times and locations search â€œScoop (York Student Food Coop)â€ on Facebook
